ygData.subject: Re: Would it be relevant to have a mutation that shift the activation function?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Greg, welcome to the group.  I believe it would be okay to let activation functions inside nodes mutate, but if that is done I would not change the neuron

Hi Greg, welcome to the group.  I believe it would be okay to let
activatio=
n functions inside nodes mutate, but if that is done I would
not change the=
 neuron to a neuron with a different innovation number.
 That would not wor=
k well for NEAT because it would mean that the same
connection connects to =
more than one neuron (i.e. in some cases the
original neuron and in some ca=
ses the new neuron), which means that
the actual network structure becomes =
ambiguous e.g. during mating of
such individuals.    

However, I understan=
d the motivation for your suggestion, but I am
guessing if the chance of mu=
tation is low enough it will not be all
that destructive to simply mutate t=
he functions while leaving the
innovation numbers for their respective node=
s unchanged.  

By the way, I would consider this issue an implementation d=
etail, so
it is not necessarily an "official" part of the HyperNEAT system =
that
it does or does not mutate the activation functions of
already-existin=
g nodes.

ken

...> wrote:
>
> Hi,

> I'm a french=
 developper working in IT software compagny completely 
> non related to IA=
. Well actually, I'm a complete newbie concerning 
> IA ;).
> Few times ago=
, I started a personnal project that aims to evolve ANN 
> with genetic pro=
gramming for a simple food gathering problem. I 
> discovered NEAT and Hype=
rNeat (and this group) by googleing the 
> subject.
> I'm still reading the=
 litterature, and I sometimes do have hard time 
> to fully understand the =
whole picture.
> (Btw, sorry for my poor english, I read a lot in english b=
ut I almost 
> never write/spoke, and thus I'm just loosing my skills over =
time.)
> 
> My question is quite simple. After a quick look on HyperNeat pa=
ckage, 
> I saw there is no mutation that shift the activation function of =
CPNN.
> So I was wondering if this mutation could be relevant, and if Neat =

> can handle this kind of mutation?
> I think it could be done by simply d=
isabling the neuron and add a new 
> neuron with the same name but with a d=
ifferent innovation number.
> 
> Regards,
> Greg.
> 
> PS: My apologies if =
the question is just stupid ;)
